text: thumb|River gods consoling Peneus for the Loss of his Daughter, Daphne In Greek mythology, Peneus (; Ancient Greek: Πηνειός) was a Thessalian river god, one of the three thousand Rivers (Potamoi), a child of Oceanus and Tethys.Hesiod, Theogony 343 == Family == The nymph Creusa bore him one son, Hypseus, who was King of the Lapiths,Diodorus Siculus, Bibliotheca historica 4.69.1; Pindar, Pythian Odes 9 and three daughters, Menippe (mother of Phrastor by Pelasgus),Dionysius of Halicarnassus, Antiquitates Romanae 1.28 DaphneOvid, Metamorphoses 1.452; Hyginus, Fabulae 203 and Stilbe.Diodorus Siculus, Bibliotheca historica 4.69.1 Some sources state that he was the father of Cyrene,Virgil, Georgics 4.320; Hyginus, Fabulae 161 alternately known as his granddaughter through Hypseus. Daphne, in an Arcadian version of the myth, was, instead, the daughter of the river god Ladon.Pausanias, Graeciae Descriptio 10.7.8; Statius, Thebaid 4.289; Nonnus, Dionysiaca 42.386 Peneus also had a son Atrax with Bura,Stephanus of Byzantium, Ethnica s.v. Atrax and Andreus with an unknown consort.Pausanias, Graeciae Descriptio 9.34.6 Tricce (or Tricca), eponym of the city Tricca, was mentioned as his daughter.Stephanus of Byzantium, Ethnica s.v. Trikkē In later accounts, Peneus was credited to be the father of Chrysogenia who consorted with Zeus and became the mother of Thissaeus.Pseudo-Clement, Recognitions 10.21-23 Meanwhile, his daughter Astabe coupled with Hermes and became the parents of Astacus, father of Iocles, father of Hipponous.Scholia on Euripides, Phoenician Women 133 According to Hellanicus, Peneus was the father of Iphis, mother of Salmoneus by Aeolus the son of Hellen.Hellanicus in scholia on Plato, Symposium 208 (p. 376) == Mythology == Eros shot Apollo with one of his arrows, causing him to fall in love with Daphne. It was Eros's plan that Daphne would scorn Apollo because Eros was angry that Apollo had made fun of his archery skills.Ovid, Metamorphoses 1.456-462 Eros also claimed to be irritated by Apollo's singing. Daphne prayed to the river god Peneus to help her. He changed her into a laurel tree, which later became sacred to Apollo (see Apollo and Daphne). ==References== ==External links== *Diodorus Siculus, The Library of History translated by Charles Henry Oldfather.
